content.description:
Fair island is a classic Newfoundland outport fishing village that was resettle during confederation. Cabins are still frequented in the area. Fair island is a remote and secluded island about 12 KM east-southeast from the town of Wareham,NL. The climbing areas vary from sunny, shady, windy,shelter depending on the time of day, weather conditions and specific climbing location. The rock is good quality solid granite. The rock ranges from smooth to very sharp, with most being sharp. Bring lots of tape. Rock all types of holds i.e. crimps, gastons, pinches, jugs. Long rails (Both sloppy and incut) and vertical and diagonal cracks are most characteristic of the area. In addition, slabby smearing sections with small micro crimps are also common. That being said, boulder problems of all angles are present and hold types are present.       
  
 Fair Island, originally called Vere Island, was one of the earliest fishing bases in Bonavista Bay; in the summer of 1681 there was a population of 16 recorded there and they were fishing from three boats. Beginning in the early 19th century, there was an increase in English settlement, and by 1806 there were two fishing rooms built in Fair Island by English men. The earliest settlers came from Devon, Cornwall, and Liverpool, England
